docs.lead_paragraph: Solidifying her effort to rein in the judicial activism of the New Jersey Supreme Court, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today nominated Jaynee LaVecchia, the state's banking commissioner and an aide to two Republican governors, to the state's highest court. The nomination, which came the day after Justice Marie T. Garibaldi announced her retirement, received generally favorable reviews from both Democrats and Republicans and was expected to win easy approval from the State Senate.

headline.main: Banking Chief Nominated To Top New Jersey Court

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Todd Whitman, solidifying her effort to rein in judicial activism of New Jersey Supreme Court, nominates Jaynee LaVecchia, state's banking commissioner, and an aide to two Republican governors, to state's highest court; nomination comes day after Justice Marie L Garibaldi announces her retirement; receives generally favorable reviews from both Democrats and Republicans; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here at the high noon of holiday shopping in Manhattan, the future of the e-commerce revolution is increasingly dependent on a low-tech, often-despised grunt: the bicycle messenger. Newly belted with two-way radios and data pagers, tracked by sophisticated routing software, these two-wheeled e-liverers are more in demand, more highly paid, better trained and, well, better uniformed than ever before.

headline.main: Selling Online, Delivering on Bikes; Low-Tech Courier Services Thrive On Growth of Web-Based Retailing

docs.abstract: High-tech e-commerce in Manhattan is increasingly dependent on low-tech bicycle messengers, who alone can prevail on an island where gridlock thwarts traditional delivery van; riders, as they call themselves, are more in demand, more highly paid, better trained and better uniformed than ever before; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three and a half years ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani transferred overall responsibility for handling major emergencies from the Police Department to a new, separate mayoral office for managing crises -- everything from a building collapse to a blackout to biological terrorism. Ever since, relations between the new agency -- the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management -- and the police have been strained, with each perceiving itself as the city's first stop in a calamity.

headline.main: Police Dept. and Emergency Agency Seem to Be in Turf War

docs.abstract: Relations between New York Police Department and Mayor's Office of Emergency Management reach new low as they gird for millennial problems ranging from terrorism to computer crashes; police are supposed to handle security and law enforcement problems, and the mayor's crisis team is supposed to handle a broader array of safety problems, but there are plenty of potential crises where those two categories overlap and where each agency might claim lead role; some city officials say there is a chance that strains could cause confusion and delays should trouble erupt on or around New Year's Eve; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Three and a half years ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani transferred overall responsibility for handling major emergencies from the Police Department to a new, separate mayoral office for managing crises -- everything from a building collapse to a...

docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, the big managed care company, was widely praised last month after it said it was eliminating tight controls over decisions by physicians, which the doctors had derided as second-guessing. United said then that doctors would no longer need advance authorization for most treatments and that the company would not refuse payment afterward. But doctors in the United network said yesterday that guidelines they had just received were still highly restrictive. They said United was still requiring prior approval, called precertification, for expensive computerized imaging tests, physical rehabilitation and prescription drugs as well as mental health and drug and alcohol treatment.

headline.main: Doctors Complain About Promise by H.M.O.

docs.abstract: Doctors in UnitedHealth Group say new guidelines received from health maintenance organization are still highly restrictive, despite company's widely praised announcement in November that it would eliminate tight controls over decisions by physicians (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found that in 9 out of 10 decisions made between doctor and patient in routine office visits, the doctor did not discuss the issue enough to allow the patient to make an informed choice. In the study, to be published in Wednesday's issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers analyzed 1,057 tapes of conversations between primary-care doctors or surgeons and their patients. The cases involved such decisions as whether to have a laboratory check thyroid hormone levels or do tests for prostate cancer.

headline.main: Study Shows Doctors Are Lax In Giving Information to Patients

docs.abstract: Study by University of Washington researchers finds that in 9 out of 10 decisions made betweenn doctor and patients during routine office visits, doctor failed to discuss issue enough to allow patient to make informed choice (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Group of Insurers to Pay for Experimental Cancer Therapy'' (Business Day, Dec. 16): Patients often refuse to take part in trials because they know they risk death in the event that they receive a placebo rather than the treatment being tested.
